where the name comes from approval testing it's about approving a result and these days some people know this by

Master so I don't like either of these names for this style of testing I think
approval testing is much more evocative of what it is so I just include these in case you were wondering ing now a test
would usually have three parts arrange act assert or given when then and the
difference with an approval test is that you're changing the way you do the assertion we replace the assert with a
print diff and that diff is the important part where you can see what you approved earlier against what you
got and if there's a bug you should be able to see oh yeah it's not giving me the right thing um and you go and fix
the bug or if actually you've changed the behavior and now the thing that you're looking at and saying ah actually
I approve that instead and the diff is what gives you the the information so it's important that the test is
producing a text that works to diff and lets you make that decision do you approve the result and the printer the
print step there is for if your test is not actually going to produce a string
you know it's producing some kind of complex object the printer is the the code that takes that object and turns it
into a string that is suitable for that diff so an approval test you could say
it has four parts arrange act print diff now if you're going to do this kind of testing I do recommend my my biggest
piece of advice get a proper approval testing tool do not do this in junit by
pasting the strings into the source code I think that is a error prone uh poor
result and there are very good tools out there and if you use them you get the benefit of all the experience of the

talking about um other things that are challenging so let's talk about garbage
collection when Java was introduced people had a lot of things to
say it was interesting for that brief period of time when it was introduced and one of the things people said was
this language has garbage collection that's terrible that's going to make all of the developers stupid because there
was this idea it's it's an extension of the idea that people had that you you're only a real developer if you write a
sembler if you're writing this C stuff you're soft you're intellectually weak
and then people kind of got over that but then Java came along and there was that that same idea was
repeated you're if you're not manually managing your memory you're student
stupid you're intellectually weak we'll come back to that because this idea is
wrong in basically every single way except for maybe the fact that manually managing memory is hard because the
thing is if you try and manually manage your
memory it's going to take you a really long time one of the things that people
like about the rust language is that it doesn't have garbage collection
but some bright Sparks took rust and they added in a garbage collector and
what they found was that people worked and they could complete a problem
in a third of the time because of the help of the garbage collector garbage collection is a really big productivity
Aid the other thing is that garbage collection is a really big correctness Aid we've had the quote a few times that
any blank contains a buggy half implementation of blank and this is
definitely true with garbage collection if you don't use automated garbage collection you will end up implementing
your own garbage collector that's worse and it will take you a lot of time to do
it and then finally what have you achieved for all of this work to make
your difficult buggy garbage collector your code probably isn't even any faster we
tend to think of garbage collection as a necessary cost often it's not even a
cost and we said yesterday that information on the internet lives forever information in books live lives
even longer and so you can still get books that say the way to tune garbage collection
is to look at your garbage collection pauses and make the amount of time spent in garbage collection pauses as short as
possible this is really terrible performance advice if you do this you
risk making the metrics that you actually care about like what is my latency what is my throughput you risk
making those metrics worse and let's look at why this might be because it is a little bit
counterintuitive garbage collection is automated memory management a program does a bunch of
things with memory manage with memory one of the things it does is access it
this is actually the bulk of your program's inter interaction with memory you want that to be
fast another thing a program does with memory is allocate it you want that to be fast and then the final thing is
freeing it and this is where we see that visible cost of garbage collection but garbage collection can actually make the
other two pieces much faster which will have a big impact on your program and so
when you think about optimizing your garbage collection what you really need to be doing is thinking holistically
about what kind of workload do I have what how does garbage collection
work and how will my workload interact with that so with garbage
collection when your computer when your program is accessing the
memory there are caches you don't ever want to go out to the ram that is
glacially slow instead you will probably get the memory that you car about from the cash if you're unlucky it's in the
level three cach that's still pretty slow might be in the level two cach but
if you're really lucky it's in the L1 cache that's where it's fastest but each cash is smaller and so what this
means is that when your program accesses memory things that were next to the
thing you just accessed will also be in the same Cash Line and so you can access
them quickly and so what this means is that you want your memory to be as compact as possible and particularly you
want things that are used at around the same time to be physically
collocated and this is called object locality so if you want to sound clever you can talk about object
locality the other thing that your program will be doing is allocating memory so when you allocate memory you
need to find a place in the Heap that is big enough for it so what it will do is it will look for the first place nope
too small look for the second place nope too small look for the third place NOP
too small look for the fourth place too small ah eventually we got there this is
really slow so what you want to be doing is having that compact Heap so that when
you need to allocate something you just go oh yeah it fit in the first place I looked there was no
problem there are two ways roughly
roughly that garbage collection can work the first is what's called Mark and sweep and so what it will do is when
there is a problem when it decides it needs to do a collection because it cannot fit that big object anywhere in
the Heap it will go through all of the objects and it will look at which ones
are still in use that's tracing it says okay yep going to keep you going to keep you going to keep you then it goes
through everything else that's in the Heap and says Okay I can I can get rid of you I can get rid of you I can get
rid of you if if there's not much garbage this is pretty
fast but it depends and then eventually you can fit
your object into the Heap there's another form of collection called copying
collection with copying collection what we do is we keep another area of the Heap just free when we do that tracing
process if something is still in use we copy it if it's not in use we never even
see it garbage costs us nothing and so what that means is when we do a
collection as long as most of what we collected was garbage The Collection has a really low cost so this is potentially
very good and you can see as well that Heap is really compact at the end so
allocation is quick memory access is likely to be quick that doesn't mean
copy and collection is always the right answer it definitely isn't but it's worth being aware of those ergonomics
when you're thinking about how to optimize so to wrap up you probably do
want to be thinking about garbage collection you probably do want to be doing some tuning of garbage collection for your workload but whatever you do
don't just tune garbage collection by trying to reduce the overhead of GC you need to take that bigger holistic
picture and look at the things you care about which is how fast your application actually runs thank
